@_stevenhill @cameans Well, yes. I think Arianism is really just a complex form of Ebionism (just as Apollinarianism is similar to Docetism)
@skubalon Brilliant. That is exactly what I needed. :-) Thor is awesome, but is not Oden.
Twitterverse: What is the comic book equivalent of Arianism (almost, but not quite God)? (I've already used Superman and Batman)

@notLane Ha. No problem.
@notLane Don't reduce me to political antagonisms! I'm a person.
@notLane But some think Lewis paints too broadly. I think it is pretty compelling (of course he's publishing my diss., so...). ;-)
@notLane "Nicaea and its Legacy" by Lewis Ayres breaks down the East/West distinction and shows all are "Pro-Nicene".
@notLane It is all Hegel right now.  Kuhn basically says Hegel is the completion of Nicene doctrine.
@notLane The NeoScholastics are repeating Aquinas; RO is repeating Augustine; there is no real contemporary metaphysic to link to Nicaea.
@notLane Well I have sympathies for that perspective. Outside of the RO crowd who is doing constructive metaphysically oriented theology?
@notLane I think Guarino tried in "Foundations of systematic theology", but I didn't really like it.
@notLane ...that doesn't mean they were false in their judgments about God nor that they couldn't be harmonized with other frameworks. 2/2
@notLane Oh, I see it now. I wasn't thinking of this especifically, but of course, if the NeoPla framework is not longer plausible... 1/2
@notLane No, but let me look at the timeline just for fun.
You have heard it said that Nicaea doctrines are foreign to New Testament; but I say the same judgment can be made with different concepts.
If you want to be a person of peace, then you really need to understand (and live into) conflict. Ignoring/minimizing conflict is not peace.
@nammonsmith I love it. I kinda started my PHD along those lines, but went a different direction.
@nammonsmith Ha. I was just kidding about that. I've written my diss. and I could tweet it out. I just sent the email. no rush on a reply.
@nammonsmith Just kidding. :-)
@nammonsmith no we didn't discuss it. I just saw it on your twitter profile. But if you can't tweet it out then you don't have enough focus!
@nammonsmith Again, great seeing you. And I'm wondering about your "dissertation thesis" thought? I'm so curious... :-)

@jrdkirk that is my point, that emergent christological and trinitarian doctrine was to keep the story of Christ straight ...
@jrdkirk and the early christian community was not a community of the text primarily but of Christ, the person and his work for them.

@jrdkirk I don't think trinitiarian theology is meant to rescue "text" at all, but to safeguard the experience of salvation and of worship.
@jrdkirk Your statement of "rescue" only looks at the biblical text, but the ancient church wasn't "only" concerned w/ the text.
@jrdkirk Does not the NT just as seriously suggest that it is the Son that gives himself for all? Which texts are we wrestling with?
@NormanStolpe I think I agree. Poor critiques of atonement often run through bad trinitarian theology.
@danrunsfast @NatePyle79 I'm for "substitutionary" but not necessarily "penal". To describe the cross as divine abuse is contrary to the NT.
@Nathaniel_g Yes, PSA may contrain strains of Arianism. But I only said "substitutionary". Some sort of substitution seems required in NT.
@notLane My FB page tells the story. But I guess I run in a pretty academic crowd.
@notLane The "divine child abuse" often does. But the Arian part was through class prep.
To say the Cross is "divine child abuse" isn't a critique of the atonement, but an affirmation Arianism (the Son is only "like" the Father).
